change.li: $Log: encyclopedia.xml,v $ Revision 1.28 2006/03/27 14:02:23 gcrane more refinements Revision 1.27 2006/03/26 04:13:20 gcrane more fixes Revision 1.26 2006/03/25 19:26:47 gcrane more fixes Revision 1.25 2006/03/25 16:38:06 gcrane Did a lot of work to clean up the base headers for subentries. These should more often now only include global descriptions, e.g, PERSON, son of A stays, but PERSON, fought at Troy goes. --> "Fought at Troy" can be one of many events and is not a global identifier Revision 1.24 2006/03/20 19:15:42 gcrane cleaned up the formatting Revision 1.23 2006/03/20 14:15:22 gcrane small changes Revision 1.20 2006/03/18 15:34:36 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.19 2006/03/18 01:14:23 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.18 2006/03/17 23:55:18 gaweaver small fixes Revision 1.17 2006/03/17 21:56:39 gaweaver Calliopi From Antiphon until Chilon Revision 1.16 2006/03/17 15:39:04 gaweaver no message Revision 1.15 2006/03/10 00:01:20 gaweaver changes made by GRC while over the atlantic Revision 1.14 2006/03/05 03:47:42 gcrane base file Revision 1.13 2006/03/04 13:13:03 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.12 2006/03/03 18:21:05 gaweaver Agenor (10) Revision 1.11 2006/02/15 16:24:46 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.10 2006/02/13 21:52:23 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.9 2006/02/13 01:57:42 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.8 2006/02/12 23:12:05 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.7 2006/02/12 15:30:08 gcrane major structural update: the descriptive info has now been moved up into the headers and id's added to div1 type="entry" Revision 1.6 2006/02/12 13:23:59 gcrane moved descriptions up into the header: the goal is to make the header more informative and thus to facilitate the mechanics of aligning entries in this list with those in Smith's etc Revision 1.5 2006/02/11 19:49:21 gcrane more small fixes to make the coding consistent Revision 1.4 2006/02/11 18:50:04 gcrane working towards moving identifiers for all entities up into the subentry HEAD Revision 1.3 2006/02/10 22:43:14 gcrane changed the structure so that every entry has a subentry -- this simplifies the structure (i hope) Revision 1.2 2005/08/18 13:53:45 packel item tags... Revision 1.1 2005/07/25 14:32:52 packel Converted to XML Revision 1.34 2003/07/01 22:16:05 yorkc Updated texts to TEI P4 and Perseus P4 extensions; minor cleanup (esp. character encodings and typos.) Revision 1.33 2000/03/16 03:17:12 dasmith Gave homonym entries a top-level header. Revision 1.32 2000/03/16 02:52:18 dasmith Added alphabetic letter DIV0s. Made entries subordinate to alphabetic letters in refsDecl. Revision 1.31 2000/03/15 15:12:45 amahoney make homonyms sub-entries Revision 1.30 2000/03/14 18:11:05 amahoney several more random issues, but the Apollodorus refs really are right now Revision 1.27 2000/03/04 20:34:25 dasmith Added separate funder entity to TEI header. Revision 1.26 2000/02/22 17:17:30 amahoney fix bibl refs to known works Revision 1.25 2000/02/04 17:58:05 dasmith Primary lookup by ID (mostly useful for internal navigation). Revision 1.24 2000/01/10 21:09:41 acsmith trying again to change pilaster def. Revision 1.23 2000/01/10 20:16:54 dasmith Fixed sentence grammar. Revision 1.22 1999/10/01 14:11:04 acsmith Amy did away with dangling ref. to Type A2 cup, and turned all Type A1 cups into Type A cups, and lower cased type in Proto type A cup. Revision 1.21 1999/09/30 21:52:22 dasmith Fixed amphorae cross-refs. Revision 1.20 1999/09/30 21:08:38 acsmith ACS fixed (hopefully!) amphorae and pyxides Revision 1.19 1999/09/29 15:55:28 dasmith Converted to TEI2 tagging.

ul.li: daughters of Zeus and Themis: Apollod. 1.2.6
predict the death of Meleager: Apollod. 1.8.1
allow Admetus a substitute to die for him: Apollod. 1.9.15
sent by Zeus to mourning Demeter: Paus. 8.42.3
Heavenly Aphrodite eldest of Fates: Paus. 1.19.2
Fortune the most powerful of the Fates: Paus. 7.26.8
images of two Fates at Delphi: Paus. 10.24.4

div3.p: Any long, flat surface of wood, stone, or marble, such as the band which divides the architrave from the frieze in the Doric order, and the surfaces into which the architrave itself is divided in the Ionic and Corinthian orders.

ul.li: title applied to elder Cyrus: Paus. 8.43.6

div3.p: the Latinized version of a satyr, after Faunus, a Latin woodland god associated with the Greek Pan

ul.li: fire hidden in a stalk of: Apollod. 1.6.3
temple of Apollo at Delphi made of fern: Paus. 10.5.10
of Dionysus: Paus. 2.24.6, Paus. 6.26.1, Paus. 7.19.10, Paus. 7.20.1, Paus. 8.23.1
hung up in sacred grove of Ganymeda at Phlius: Paus. 2.13.4, and in temple of Athena Alea at Tegea: Paus. 8.47.2
image of Enyalius in fetters: Paus. 3.15.7
image of Eurynome in fetters (golden chains): Paus. 8.41.6
bestowed by Demeter on Phytalus: Paus. 1.37.2
Greek names for wild fig-tree: Paus. 4.20.2
of Cadmus's ships: images made out of: Paus. 9.16.3
figure-heads of ships dedicated by Athenians at Delphi: Paus. 10.11.6

div3.p: A narrow, flat, plain undecorated band, specifically naming the flat space between the flutes of an Ionic shaft.

ul.li: bound on head as mark of victory: Paus. 6.4.5, Paus. 9.22.3

div3.p: decorative attachment at the top of a stele or other form; terminating element in furniture or architecture

ul.li: Demophon put on the fire by Demeter to make him immortal: Apollod. 1.5.1, Apollod. 1.5.2
stolen by Prometheus and given to men: Apollod. 1.6.3
Herakles throws his children into the: Apollod. 2.4.11
Achilles put by Thetis on the, to make him immortal: Apollod. 3.13.5, Apollod. 3.13.6
Broteas throws himself into the: Apollod. E.1.24, Apollod. E.2.2
sacred fire into which the Taurians throw strangers: Apollod. E.6.25
perpetual fire at Argos, 2.19.5, on hearth of Prytaneum at Olympia: Paus. 5.15.9, in sanctuary of Demeter and Maid at Mantinea: Paus. 8.9.2, and in sanctuary of Pan at Lycosura: Paus. 8.37.11
fetched by Argives from sanctuary of Pyronian Artemis for Lernaean rites: Paus. 8.15.9
fire-brand on which life of Meleager depended: Paus. 10.31.4

div2.subhead: first fruits, sacrificed to the gods

ul.li: not caught in certain waters: Paus. 1.38.1, Paus. 3.21.5, Paus. 7.22.4

div3.p: A type of plate, or flattish disc, with a turned down lip, and a low, sloping central hollow. The foot, on the underside, usually takes a low ring shape.
History: The shape appears in Attic pottery at the end of the fifth century and flourishes in Campanian wares and in the red-figure pottery of Apulia.
Term: The fish plate takes its modern name from the fact that so many are decorated along their upper surface with fish.
Slabs of stone more finished, and slightly thinner than the lower courses, laid as flooring.

Description: Generally rectangular in shape, these slabs of stone were put down over the lower courses of the foundation, on the stylobate, to produce a regularness to the floor, often indicating a more finely finished temple or building. Often laid when the lower courses are irregular, such as geometric foundations.

ul.li: commands Roman army in Greece: Paus. 7.7.9
invites Elateans to revolt from Macedonia: Paus. 10.34.4
both fine and common: grown in Elis: Paus. 6.26.6
fine flax of Elis: Paus. 5.5.2, Paus. 7.21.14

div2.subhead: flesh, of infants eaten by women in Bacchic frenzy

ul.li: driven out of Olympia by Eleans: Paus. 5.14.1
sacrifice and prayers offered to Fly-catcher at Aliphera: Paus. 8.26.7
in Deucalion's time: Apollod. 1.7.2, Apollod. 1.9.12, Paus. 1.40.1, Paus. 5.8.1, Paus. 10.6.2(See Deucalion)
where the water of the flood ran away: Paus. 1.18.7

div3.p: One of the carved vertical concave grooves used to decorate a column shaft or pilaster.

Description: Flutes are used in all the orders except for the Tuscan. In the Doric column the shaft is usually built up of several separate drums, to which fluting (the act of carving the flutes) was applied after the columns were erected. The usual number in the Doric order is twenty, and they are separated by a sharp edge or arris.The flutes are sometimes filled with a round, convex moulding or bead. This does not, generally, extend higher than one-third the height of the shaft. In the Ionic order the number of flutes is twenty-four; they are relatively deep, and elliptical in section. In the Ionic order these flutes are separated by a narrow flat band called a fillet. In the earlier years the number was not fixed, and as many as thirty-two channels appear; later twenty-four was canonical.

ul.li: formerly three kinds of flutes: Paus. 9.12.5
played while Lacedaemonians march to battle: Paus. 3.17.5
thrown away by Athena, and picked up by Marsyas: Paus. 1.24.1

div3.p: Follower does not mean pupil. A follower is a vase painter who is influenced by another artist or group, but does not have a close/direct connection with the painter(s).

ul.li: originally the only contest at Olympia: Paus. 5.8.6
of goddesses: Paus. 8.37.3, of Zeus: Paus. 5.11.7
gods of the fore-temple at Thebes: Paus. 9.10.2
sanctuaries and temples: Paus. 1.43.6, Paus. 2.2.8, Paus. 2.7.5, Paus. 2.20.3, Paus. 2.35.3, Paus. 4.30.3, Paus. 6.25.4, Paus. 8.30.7, Paus. 9.16.1
of Trajan at Rome with bronze roof: Paus. 5.12.6, Paus. 10.5.11
Teumesian fox turned into stone: Paus. 9.19.1
released from serfdom by Augustus: Paus. 3.21.6

div3.p: an adjective applied to statues that are made to stand on their own (usually on a statue base), or at least apart from a background plane (as with relief sculpture)
The middle component of the entablature, resting on the architrave and below the cornice, may be decorated, such as a Zophorus.
Description: In the Doric order the frieze is decorated with two alternating motives. While in the Ionic order the frieze is a decoratively carved band.

ul.li: on outside of temple of Zeus at Olympia: Paus. 5.10.5
laid before image of Demeter remains fresh throughout the year: Paus. 9.19.5
fruits of all sorts (except pomegranates) offered in sanctuary of Mistress: Paus. 8.37.7

div2.subhead: Fruit-bearers, name of Demeter and the Maid

ul.li: of Spartan kings and nobles: Paus. 4.14.4
born of the flowing blood of sky: Apollod. 1.1.2
first represented with snakes in their hair by Aeschylus: Paus. 1.28.6
Furies of Clytaemnestra: Paus. 8.34.4, of Laius and Oedipus: Paus. 9.5.15
daughters of Pandareos given over to F. Paus. 10.30.2
the Fury hearkens to Althaea's curses: Paus. 10.31.3
Demeter Fury at Thelpusa: Paus. 8.25.4, Apollod. vol.1.373
of Eriphyle pursues her murderer Alcmaeon: Apollod. 3.7.5
